qas.question: Who is a notable subjective idealist?
What famous philosopher was a transcendental idealist?
Who are subjective idealists opposed to?
Along with Plato, what notable philosopher rejected epistemological idealism?
Who believed the essence of reality to be composed of monads?
What idealist is George Berkeley most similar to?

plausible_answers.text: whether all of our putative outer experience is not mere imagining

qas.question: Berkeley defines idealism by saying we can never be sure of what?
What did Kant say reality needed to admit?
Who are subjective idealists in agreement with?
Who disagreed with Plato's rejection of epistemological idealism?

context: Subjective idealists like <a0_0>George Berkeley<a0_0/> are anti-<a2_0>realists<a2_0/> in terms of a mind-independent world, whereas transcendental idealists like <a1_0><b5_0>Immanuel Kant<b5_0/><a1_0/> are strong skeptics of such a world, affirming epistemological and not metaphysical idealism. Thus Kant defines idealism as "the assertion that we can never be certain <b6_0>whether all of our putative outer experience is not mere imagining<b6_0/>". He claimed that, according to idealism, "the reality of external objects does not admit of <b7_0>strict proof<b7_0/>. On the contrary, however, the reality of the object of our internal sense (of myself and state) is clear immediately through consciousness."  However, not all idealists restrict the real or the knowable to our immediate subjective experience. <b8_0>Objective<b8_0/> idealists make claims about a transempirical world, but simply deny that this world is essentially divorced from or ontologically prior to the mental. Thus Plato and <a3_0><b9_0>Gottfried Leibniz<b9_0/><a3_0/> affirm an objective and knowable reality transcending our subjective awareness—a rejection of epistemological idealism—but propose that this reality is grounded in ideal entities, a form of metaphysical idealism. Nor do all metaphysical idealists agree on the nature of the ideal; for Plato, the fundamental entities were non-mental abstract forms, while for <a4_0>Leibniz<a4_0/> they were proto-mental and concrete monads.
